page.title: 19THE LEGEND OF SIGAR-NORTHAW.
page.content: Northaw Woods was once owned by the Abbot of St Albans and the "Hermit" Monks.These monks preferred to live quietly and spent most of their time praying.In 948 they built a small chapel to use,on the site of the Parish Church of St.Thomas of Canterbury.One monk,Sigar, loved all woodland animals especially the birds. Sigar would travel by night to St.Albans to attend and worship in matins.After these,he would return to another full day of prayer and study in the peace of the wood.The stillness was often broken by the songs of the Nightingales,so he prayed to God to have them removed.While he lived nightingales avoided the place.Sigar died and was buried in the Abbey at St.Albans and for many days after the city was filled with Northaw birds! Many years later the birds returned.
